foreword.title: Foreword
foreword.p: ISO (the International Organization for Standardization) is a worldwide federation of national standards bodies (ISO member bodies). The work of preparing International Standards is normally carried out through ISO technical committees. Each member body interested in a subject for which a technical committee has been established has the right to be represented on that committee. International organizations, governmental and non-governmental, in liaison with ISO, also take part in the work. ISO collaborates closely with the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) on all matters of electrotechnical standardization.

The procedures used to develop this document and those intended for its further maintenance are described in the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 1. In particular the different approval criteria needed for the different types of ISO documents should be noted. This document was drafted in accordance with the editorial rules of the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2 (see www.iso.org/directives).

Attention is drawn to the possibility that some of the elements of this document may be the subject of patent rights. ISO shall not be held responsible for identifying any or all such patent rights. Details of any patent rights identified during the development of the document will be in the Introduction and/or on the ISO list of patent declarations received (see www.iso.org/patents).
Any trade name used in this document is information given for the convenience of users and does not constitute an endorsement.

For an explanation on the voluntary nature of standards, the meaning of ISO specific terms and expressions related to conformity assessment, as well as information about ISO’s adherence to the World Trade Organization (WTO) principles in the Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT) see the following URL: www.iso.org/iso/foreword.html.
This document was prepared by Technical Committee ISO/TC 154, Processes, data elements and documents in commerce, industry and administration.

This document is amongst a series of International Standards dealing with date and time by Technical Committee ISO/TC 154, Processes, data elements and documents in commerce, industry and administration, WG 5 Date and time.
This is the first edition of this document.

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.p: ISO Recommendations and Standards relating to date and time concepts have been available since 1971.
This document presents terms and definitions for selected concepts relevant to date and time concepts and of their representation.
Specifically, the terminology presented in this document:

li.p: serve as a sound basis in the understanding of date and time;
guide new developments in the field by underpinning mutual understanding; and
serve as a quick and handy reference for those newly inaugurated to this field.

introduction.p: Most terms in this document were sourced from and .

clause.title: Scope
clause.p: This document provides a concept system and a standard set of terminology related to date and time, from basic concepts to those of their representation.
The scope of the vocabulary provided in this document corresponds to that of ISO/TC 154/WG 5: Representation of dates and times.

definition.p: time () on the calendar () time scale ()

termnote.p: Common forms of date include: calendar date (), ordinal date (), and week date ().

definition.p: mark attributed to an instant () or a time interval () on a specified time scale ()

termnote.p: The term “time” is often used in common language. However, it should only be used if the meaning is clearly visible from the context.
On a time scale consisting of successive time intervals, such as a clock () or calendar (), distinct instants may be expressed by the same time.
This definition corresponds closely with the definition of the term “date” in 113-01-12.

definition.p: point on the time axis ()

termnote.p: An instantaneous event occurs at a specific instant.

definition.p: mathematical representation of the succession in time according to the space-time model of instantaneous events along a unique axis

termnote.p: According to the theory of special relativity, the time axis depends on the choice of a spatial reference frame.
In 113-01-03, time according to the space-time model is defined to be the one-dimensional subspace of space-time, locally orthogonal to space.

modification.p: The words “according to the space-time” have been added; the phrase “special theory of relativity” has been changed to “theory of special relativity” for clarity; Note 2 to entry has been added.

definition.p: system of ordered marks which can be attributed to instants () on the time axis (), one instant being chosen as the origin

termnote.p: A time scale may amongst others be chosen as:

li.p: continuous with discontinuities, e.g. Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) () due to leap seconds (), standard time () due to summer time and winter time;
successive steps, e.g. calendars (), where the time axis () is split up into a succession of consecutive time intervals () and the same mark is attributed to all instants of each time interval;

modification.p: The words “amongst others” in Note 1 to entry have been added; NOTEs 2 and 3 have been deleted.

definition.p: part of the time axis () limited by two instants () and, unless otherwise stated, the limiting instants themselves

modification.p: the words “and, unless otherwise stated, the limiting instants themselves” have been added; the NOTEs have been deleted.

definition.p: unit of measurement of a duration ()

termexample.p: Calendar year, calendar month, calendar day are time scale units of the Gregorian calendar.
Clock hour, clock minutes, clock seconds are time scale units of the 24-hour clock.

definition.p: non-negative quantity of time equal to the difference between the final and initial instants () of a time interval ()

termnote.p: The duration is one of the base quantities in the International System of Quantities (ISQ) on which the International System of Units (SI) is based. The term “time” instead of “duration” is often used in this context and also for an infinitesimal duration.

For the term “duration”, expressions such as “time” or “time interval” are often used, but the term “time” is not recommended in this sense and the term “time interval” is deprecated in this sense to avoid confusion with the concept of “time interval”.

The exact duration of a time scale unit () depends on the time scale () used. For example, the durations of a year, month, week, day, hour, or minute, may depend on when they occur [in a Gregorian calendar (), a calendar month () can have a duration of 28, 29, 30, or 31 days; in a 24-hour clock () a clock minute () can have a duration of 59, 60, or 61 seconds, etc.]. Therefore, the exact duration can only be evaluated if the exact duration of each is known.
This definition is closely related to NOTE 1 of “duration” in 113-01-13.

definition.p: time scale () suited for intra-day time measurements

termnote.p: clock second (), clock minute () and clock hour () are often time scale units () included in a clock.

termexample.p: The 24-hour clock () is a type of clock.

definition.p: clock () that subdivides a calendar day () into 24 clock hours ()

termexample.p: UTC () a type of 24-hour clock that is often used as the basis time scale of standard times.

definition.p: series of consecutive time intervals () of identical duration ()

termnote.p: If the duration of the time intervals is measured in calendar () entities, the duration of each time interval depends on the calendar dates () of its start and its end.
If the starting instants of time intervals are repeated according to a set of rules, the “repeat rules for recurring time intervals” in 5 apply.

definition.p: time scale () with the same rate as International Atomic Time (TAI), but differing from TAI only by an integral number of seconds ()

termnote.p: UTC is a basis time scale () commonly used across the world from which local time scales are derived.
UTC is produced by the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM), i.e. the International Bureau of Weights and Measures.

TAI is a continuous time scale produced by the BIPM based on the best realizations of the SI second. TAI is a realization of Terrestrial Time (TT) with the same rate as that of TT, as defined by IAU Resolution B1.9 (2010): Re-definition of Terrestrial Time TT.

termsource.origin: BIPM Recommendation CCTF 3 (2017): Recommendation on the definition of timescales

modification.p: The definition of TAI has been included as Note 3 to entry.

definition.p: time of day () in UTC ()
time scale () established to serve as reference time by a competent authority

termnote.p: The basis time scale is not always legally UTC in all countries.

termexample.p: UTC (), TAI, GPS system time, Galileo system time, BeiDou system time, LORAN station system time are basis time scales in current use.

definition.p: time scale () derived from a basis time scale () with a time shift () established by a competent authority

termnote.p: The time shift of a standard time may vary in the course of a year, such as due to daylight savings.
Many standard times use UTC as their basis and are often associated with a geographical location. A timezone may be associated with one or more standard times.
This definition corresponds closely to, but is more general than, the definition of the term “standard time” in 113-01-17.

termexample.p: Some standard times do not vary within a year, such as US Eastern Standard Time (EST), US Eastern Daylight Time (EDT), Australia Western Standard Time (AWST), China Standard Time (CST), Hong Kong Standard Time (HKT), Korea Standard Time (KST) and Japanese Standard Time (JST).
Some standard times vary within a year, such as US Eastern Time (ET) and Australian Central Standard Time (ACST).

definition.p: locally-applicable standard time ()
time () occurring within a calendar day ()

termnote.p: Generally, time of day relates to the duration () elapsed after the beginning of the day. However, this correlation breaks when changes occur in the time scale () that applies to the time of day, such as time shifts () and leap seconds ().
This definition corresponds closely with the definition of “clock time” given in 113-01-18, except that the concepts of duration () and time scale () are not used in this definition.

definition.p: time of day () in a basis time scale ()

termexample.p: UTC of day () is a type of basis time of day.

definition.p: time of day () in a local time scale ()
time scale () that uses the time scale unit () of calendar day () as its basic unit

termnote.p: calendar month () and calendar year () are time scale units often included in a calendar.

termexample.p: The Gregorian calendar () is a type of calendar.

definition.p: calendar () in general use that defines a calendar year () that closely approximates the tropical year
calendar year () in the Gregorian calendar () that has 365 calendar days ()
calendar year () in the Gregorian calendar () that has 366 calendar days ()

termnote.p: A leap year is a calendar year whose year number is divisible by four and is not a centennial year (), or a centennial year whose year number is divisible by four hundred.

definition.p: calendar year () in the Gregorian calendar () whose year number is divisible without remainder by one hundred

calendar () based on an unbounded series of contiguous calendar weeks () that uses the time scale unit () of calendar week as its basic unit to represent a calendar year (), according to the rule that the first calendar week of a calendar year is the week including the first Thursday of that year, and that the last one is the week immediately preceding the first calendar week of the next calendar year

termnote.p: This rule is based on the principle that a week belongs to the calendar year in which the majority of its calendar days () belongs.
In the week calendar, calendar days of the first and last calendar week of a calendar year may belong to the previous and the next calendar year respectively in the Gregorian calendar ().

definition.p: intentional time step of one second () to adjust UTC () to ensure appropriate agreement with UT1, a time scale () based on the rotation of the Earth

termnote.p: See also .

An inserted second is called a positive leap second and an omitted second is called a negative leap second. A positive leap second is inserted after [23:59:59Z] and can be represented as [23:59:60Z]. A negative leap second is achieved by the omission of [23:59:59Z]. Insertion or omission takes place as determined by the International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service (IERS), normally on 30 June or 31 December, but if necessary on 31 March or 30 September.

definition.p: constant duration () difference between times () of two time scales ()
calendar date which is an estimate whose value is asserted to be possibly correct

termnote.p: The degree of confidence in approximation depends on the application.

definition.p: calendar date whose source is considered dubious ()
calendar date of which a part is unstated

termnote.p: The unstated part can be year, year and month, month, month and day, or year and day. It is unstated because it has not (yet) been assigned (it might be assigned in the future), or because it is classified, or unknown, or for any other reason.

definition.p: not to be relied upon
symbol that indicates certain qualification to a value it applies to

termexample.p: The symbol [?] indicates that the value it applies to is uncertain

definition.p: repeatedly occurring day in a calendar that is represented by criteria set by one or more selection rules (), but does not always resolve to a fixed calendar day in every repeating cycle

termnote.p: The selection of this term pays homage to the phrase “movable feast” used in some calendars to indicate the rule-based determination of annual events.

termexample.p: Thanksgiving Day in the U.S. and Canada are considered movable days, set to the fourth Thursday in November and the second Monday in October, respectively.
First Day of Summer (sumardagurinn fyrsti) in Iceland is considered a movable day, set to the first Thursday after April 18th.
Father’s Day is celebrated on the third Sunday in June in North America, and is considered a movable day.

definition.p: duration in the reverse direction to the proceeding time scale
single function or group of functions
value assigned to a subset of features () within a profile ()

termnote.p: A profile may refer to these conformity levels to facilitate the specification of conformance to the profile.

definition.p: subset of features () described in a standard or a set of standards

termnote.p: A community may develop a profile to describe how to carry out functions or apply features specified in a standard or family of standards in a manner relevant to that community.

A profile often describes what features are to be supported and how to apply those features. In cases where multiple methods are allowed for a required feature, a profile may select a single method. In cases where a particular function allows different interpretations, a profile may select a single interpretation or provide clarification. A profile may list out features that need not be supported. It may specify several conformity levels ().

definition.p: profile () whose base standard is the ISO 8601 series
set of eligible time intervals () and selection rules () that allows computation of a set of matching instants ()
rule specifying restrictions on the value of a time scale component
set of repeating instants, calculated by a specified start instant and specified duration gap between the repeating instants
time interval eligible for matching using selection rules ()
set of instants, computed by a repeat rule (), that belongs within eligible time intervals () and fulfills criteria set by specified selection rules ()
expression that specifies modification of a date and time expression with a duration
time scale component that composes the duration date and time representation
time scale unit composed of a duration expressed by one or more durational units ()
grouping composed of time scale components of a lower order than the calendar year time scale
sub-year grouping () where the duration of its elements sum up to the duration of one calendar year

termnote.p: A normal sub-year grouping can be composed of time scale units with different durations.

termexample.p: The bimonthly time scale unit can be repeated into a normal sub-year grouping, where 12 months can be divided cleanly by units of 2 months each.
The four seasons in the commonly used four season calendar () make a normal sub-year grouping as the duration of their combination is exactly one calendar year.
Six season calendars used in various cultures are examples of normal sub-year groupings.

definition.p: difference between mean solar time and apparent solar time, which varies with time within a calendar year

termnote.p: A clock is a type of device that measures mean solar time; a sundial is a type of device that measures apparent solar time.

definition.p: element of a normal sub-year grouping (), amongst which the transition between each element can be based on calendrical, meteorological, astronomical, solar or ecological events
calendar in general use resulting from the division of a calendar year into four seasons ()

termnote.p: A single calendar date may represent different seasons depending on local customs or location, such as the difference between the northern or southern hemispheres.
The four seasons are namely spring (), summer (), autumn (), and winter ()

definition.p: season () in the four-season calendar () following winter () and preceding summer ()
season () in the four-season calendar () following spring () and preceding autumn ()
season () in the four-season calendar () following summer () and preceding winter ()
season () in the four-season calendar () following autumn () and preceding spring ()
base unit of duration () measurement in the International System of Units (SI)

termnote.p: As defined by the CGPM (Conférence générale des poids et mesures, General Conference on Weights and Measures) on the proposal of the CIPM (Comité International des Poids et Mesures, International Committee of Weights and Measures).
See also .

definition.p: time scale unit () whose duration () is one second ()

termnote.p: Clock second is in common parlance often referred to as second, however in this document clock second and second have different definitions.

definition.p: duration () of 60 seconds ()

termnote.p: See also .
The duration of a minute is 60 seconds except if modified by the insertion or deletion of a leap second

definition.p: time scale unit () whose duration is one minute ()

termnote.p: Clock minute is in common parlance often referred to as minute, however in this document clock minute and minute have different definitions.

definition.p: duration () of 60 minutes ()

termnote.p: See also .

definition.p: time scale unit () whose duration () is one hour ()

termnote.p: Clock hour is in common parlance often referred to as hour, however in this document clock hour and hour have different definitions.

definition.p: particular calendar day () represented by its calendar year (), its calendar month () and its calendar day of month ()
particular calendar day () represented by its calendar year () and its calendar day of year ()
particular calendar day () represented by its calendar year () to which its calendar week () belongs, its calendar week of year (), and its calendar day of week ()
duration () of a calendar day ()

termnote.p: The term “day” applies also to the duration of any time interval () which starts at a certain time of day () on a certain calendar day and ends at the same time of day on the next calendar day.
See also .

definition.p: time scale unit () starting at the beginning of the day and ending with the beginning of the next day [the latter being the starting instant () of the next calendar day]

termnote.p: Calendar day is in common parlance often referred to as day, however in this document calendar day and day have different definitions.
The duration () of a calendar day using the 24-hour clock () is 24 hours (); except if modified by:

li.p: the insertion or deletion of leap seconds (), by decision of the IERS; or
the insertion or deletion of other time intervals, as may be prescribed by local authorities to alter the time scale () of local time.

definition.p: day amongst the sequence of week calendar () days, namely, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday or Sunday
ordinal number of a calendar day () within a calendar month ()
ordinal number of a calendar day () within a calendar year ()
duration () of a calendar week ()

termnote.p: The term “week” applies also to the duration of any time interval () which starts at a certain time of day () at a certain calendar day of week () and ends at the same time of day at the same calendar day of week in the next calendar week.

definition.p: time scale unit () of seven calendar days () within a single calendar year () which begins on Monday and ends on Sunday, according to the week calendar ()
ordinal number of a calendar week () within a calendar year () of the week calendar ()
duration () of a calendar month ()

termnote.p: The term “month” applies also to the duration of any time interval () which starts at a certain time of day () at a certain calendar day () of the calendar month and ends at the same time of day at the same calendar day of the next calendar month, if it exists.
In certain applications a month is considered as a duration of 30 calendar days, but such usage is not supported by this document.

definition.p: time scale unit () resulting from a defined division of a calendar year (), each containing a specific number of calendar days ()

termnote.p: A calendar month is in common parlance often referred to as month, however in this document calendar month and month have different definitions.

definition.p: duration () of a calendar year ()

termnote.p: In the Gregorian calendar (), a year has 365 or 366 days (). The duration is 366 days if the corresponding time interval () begins February 28 or earlier in a leap year () or March 2 or later in a year immediately preceding a leap year. If the interval begins February 29 (on a leap year), or March 1 of a year preceding a leap year, the end date has to be agreed on. Otherwise the duration is 365 days.

The term “year” applies also to the duration of any time interval () which starts at a certain time of day () at a certain calendar date () of the calendar year and ends at the same time of day at the same calendar date of the next calendar year with the exception noted in Note 1 to entry.

definition.p: time scale unit () defined by the calendar () system
time scale unit () of 10 calendar years (), beginning with a year whose year number is divisible without remainder by ten

termnote.p: Decade is also used to refer to an arbitrary duration () of 10 years, however decade is not used as such in this document.

definition.p: time scale unit () of 100 calendar years () duration (), beginning with a year whose year number is divisible without remainder by 100

termnote.p: Century is also used to refer to an arbitrary duration of 100 years, however century is not used as such in this document.

termexample.p: The “19th century” covers the years 1800 through 1899 as in common parlance.

definition.p: expression indicating a time (), time interval () or recurring time interval

termexample.p: ‘2018-08-01’ is a date and time expression that indicates the first day of August of 2018 in the Gregorian calendar ().

definition.p: representation of the format of one or more date and time expressions ()

termexample.p: [date] is a date and time representation that can be expanded as [year][month][day], which itself can be expanded into [YYYY][MM][DD]; ‘20180801’ is a date and time expression that conforms to this representation.

definition.p: representation of a time scale unit () within a date and time expression () or a representation ()

termnote.p: A time scale component is considered of a higher order of another, if the time scale unit it represents has a strictly larger time interval () than that of that another; the latter time scale component is therefore considered to be of a lower order.

Common usage of this term often omits the leading phrase “time scale”, such as representing a “time scale component calendar year” by just “calendar year component”. This usage is deemed accepted in this document.

termexample.p: calendar year (), calendar month (), calendar day (), clock hour (), clock minute (), clock second () are time scale components of a complete representation ().
The calendar year time scale component is considered of a higher order than the calendar month time scale component, which is in turn of a higher order than the calendar day time scale component.

definition.p: date and time representation () that does not include separators between its time scale components ()
extension of the basic format () that includes separators between its time scale components ()
date and time representation () that includes all the time scale components () associated with the expression ()
abbreviation of a date and time representation () by omission of lower order time scale components ()
expansion of a date and time representation () by addition of a decimal fraction to the lowest order time scale component ()
character used in a representation with decimal fraction () to separate the integer part from the decimal fraction of a number

termnote.p: The representations of the decimal signs (period or comma) and their usage rules are specified in .

clause.title: General
clause.p: This clause describes commonly used concepts for the usage of time scale systems.

clause.title: Day
clause.p: A day is a time scale unit that approximates the duration taken by the Earth for completing one rotation with respect to the Sun.

clause.title: Month
clause.p: A month is a time scale unit, that traditionally approximated the duration taken between two successive syzygies of the Moon.

clause.title: Year
clause.p: A year is a time scale unit that approximates the orbital period of the Earth around the Sun.

clause.title: Second
clause.p: A second is a time scale unit defined by the CIPM in the SI system based on radiation periods of the caesium-133 atom.
Traditionally, it represented a subdivision of the day being 1 / 86400 of a day.

clause.title: Minute
clause.p: A minute is a time scale unit often defined as 1 / 60 of an hour or 60 seconds.

clause.title: Hour
clause.p: An hour is a time scale unit often defined as 1 / 24 of a day or 3600 seconds.

clause.title: General
clause.p: Date and time organizing systems are often used for social, administrative and religious purposes, in order to allow an easier identification method of dates and times through the usage of hierarchical time scale units.

clause.title: Calendar
clause.p: A calendar is a system to organize days, based on time intervals marked by events related to the astronomical motion of planetary bodies, synchronized to the tropical year and orbital motion of the Earth.
A calendar system often includes the time scale components year, month and day.

clause.title: Clock
clause.p: The clock is a time scale used to identify and measure smaller time intervals within a day.
A clock system often includes the time scale components hour, minute and second.

International Electrotechnical Vocabulary — Part 113: Physics for electrotechnology
bibitem.abstract:
IEC 60050-113:2011 gives the general terminology on physical concepts used in the fields of electricity, electronics and telecommunications. Its target is to collect the most usual concepts in space and time, macroscopic physics, mechanics, thermodynamics, particle physics, and solid-state physics, and to present them as terms and descriptions given in logical order according to their interdependence. The descriptions are definitions from the terminological point of view, but they are not always complete definitions in physical sense. Their main goal is to distinguish among particular concepts. In consequence, this part of the IEV should not be regarded as a physical textbook, but rather as a set of terms with their equivalents in many languages and with descriptions in the main IEV languages. This first edition cancels and replaces Sections 111-13, 111-14 and 111-16 of International Standard IEC 60050-111:1996 and its Amendment 1:2005.
It has the status of a horizontal standard in accordance with IEC Guide 108. The contents of the corrigendum of September 2011 have been included in this copy.
